oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Abortion in Dairy Cattle Placed in Proper Perspective
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gibson, Charles D.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: dairy herd
abortion
economic importance
embryonic mortality
fertilization failure
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Abortion problems in the well-managed dairy herd today are of a self-limiting nature in most cases. However, the problem of abortion is a highly visible one to the client, and as a result you, as a practitioner, are involved with an upset client who wants answers quickly. The economic importance of abortion in a well-managed herd, vaccinated for prevention of endemic diseases, appears very low compared to the economic losses from embryonic mortality and fertilization failure in reproductive dysgenesis.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 1977; 111-113
